raw_text:
Mobiles rack up 20 years of use
 
 Mobile phones in the UK are celebrating their 20th anniversary this weekend.
 
 Britain's first mobile phone call was made across the Vodafone network on 1 January 1985 by veteran comedian Ernie Wise. In the 20 years since that day, mobile phones have become an integral part of modern life and now almost 90% of Britons own a handset. Mobiles have become so popular that many people use their handset as their only phone and rarely use a landline.
 
 The first ever call over a portable phone was made in 1973 in New York but it took 10 years for the first commercial mobile service to be launched. The UK was not far behind the rest of the world in setting up networks in 1985 that let people make calls while they walked. The first call was made from St Katherine's dock to Vodafone's head office in Newbury which at the time was over a curry house. For the first nine days of 1985 Vodafone was the only firm with a mobile network in the UK. Then on 10 January Cellnet (now O2) launched its service. Mike Caudwell, spokesman for Vodafone, said that when phones were launched they were the size of a briefcase, cost about £2,000 and had a battery life of little more than 20 minutes.
 
 "Despite that they were hugely popular in the mid-80s," he said. "They became a yuppy must-have and a status symbol among young wealthy business folk." This was also despite the fact that the phones used analogue radio signals to communicate which made them very easy to eavesdrop on. He said it took Vodafone almost nine years to rack up its first million customers but only 18 months to get the second million. "It's very easy to forget that in 1983 when we put the bid document in we were forecasting that the total market would be two million people," he said. "Cellnet was forecasting half that." Now Vodafone has 14m customers in the UK alone. Cellnet and Vodafone were the only mobile phone operators in the UK until 1993 when One2One (now T-Mobile) was launched. Orange had its UK launch in 1994. Both newcomers operated digital mobile networks and now all operators use this technology. The analogue spectrum for the old phones has been retired. Called Global System for Mobiles (GSM) this is now the most widely used phone technology on the planet and is used to help more than 1.2 billion people make calls. Mr Caudwell said the advent of digital technology also helped to introduce all those things, such as text messaging and roaming that have made mobiles so popular.
llama3.2:1b: Mobile phones in the UK celebrate their 20th anniversary this weekend with Britain's first mobile phone call being made by veteran comedian Ernie Wise on January 1, 1985.
Mobile phones became an integral part of modern life over two decades ago and now almost 90% of Britons own a handset.
llama3.2:3b: The UK's first mobile call was made in 1985 by Ernie Wise on Vodafone's network.
Mobile phones have become a staple of modern life, with almost 90% of Britons owning a handset.
The first commercial mobile service launched 10 years later, and the technology has evolved rapidly since then.
Today, Vodafone has 14m customers in the UK, while Cellnet/O2 has around half that number.
Digital technology has introduced features such as text messaging, roaming, and helped retire the analogue spectrum.
gemma2:2b: Mobile phones in the UK are celebrating their 20th anniversary this weekend.
They have become an integral part of modern life with almost 90% of Britons owning a hand set.
The first mobile phone call was made on January 1, 1985, by Ernie Wise.
In the early days, phones were bulky, expensive and used analog signals.
Vodafone became the only operator in the UK for nine days before Cellnet launched its service.
Both companies saw explosive growth with Vodafone reaching 1 million customers in a few months and then 2 million.
By 1993, new digital networks (One2One and Orange) entered the market.
The transition to GSM technology has revolutionized mobile communications worldwide.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Mobiles are now almost 90% owned in the UK.
Most Britons still own a phone even though they use landlines regularly.
The first-ever mobile call was on January 1, 1985, when Ernie Wise used Vodafone's network to make his first call across London.
Mobiles have become very popular and now almost half of Britons own one or more phones.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Mobile phones in the UK reached their 20th anniversary on January 1, 2005.
Since then, they have become an integral part of modern life with over 90% of Britons owning a handset and being used exclusively for calls instead of landlines.

In 1983, Vodafone was the first mobile operator in the UK, launching a service that used analogue radio signals which allowed them to quickly gain millions of customers within just nine years before Cellnet (now O2) launched their own service on January 10, 1985.
The introduction of digital technology has led to more features like text messaging and roaming becoming popular with mobile phones.
qwen2.5:3b: Mobile phones in the UK celebrate their 20th anniversary since the first call was made on January 1, 1985 by Ernie Wise.
The UK became the first country to set up networks allowing people to make calls while walking.
Vodafone launched its service in 1985 and within nine days Cellnet (now O2) followed with their network.
Initially bulky and expensive ($2000), mobiles were a status symbol for young, wealthy business professionals in the mid-80s.
Despite early security concerns due to analogue signals being easily intercepted, Vodafone rapidly grew its customer base, doubling from one million to two million customers within 18 months.

The advent of digital technology, particularly GSM (Global System for Mobile Communications), has made mobile phones more popular with features such as text messaging and roaming now available globally.
opencoder:1.5b:
The output of this task is a summary of the given text, which preserves key ideas and details:

"20 years of use of mobile phones in the UK".
"A 90% increase in usage in modern life".
"The first ever call over a portable phone".
"In 1973 from St Katherine's dock to Vodafone's head office".
"This was about the first commercial mobile service in the UK.
"The first call was made from Newbury, but it took 10 years for the first commercial mobile service to be launched.".
"Vodafone set up networks in 1985 that let people make calls while they walked and began to rack up its first million customers in 1983".
"This technology has become a status symbol among young wealthy business folk".
"In 1993, T-Mobile launched which replaced Orange's launch in 1994".
"The advent of digital technology has introduced all those things like text messaging and roaming that have made mobiles so popular".
"Finally, it's clear why mobile phones are so popular: they’re easy to make calls from and allow for a lot of flexibility in communication.
smollm:1.7b: The UK's first mobile phone call was made on January 1st, 1985 by Ernie Wise, a veteran comedian who had been one of the first people in the UK to own a handset.
The first mobile phone service in the UK was launched on January 10th, 1985 and it was called Cellnet (now O2).
It was launched by Vodafone, which is still one of the largest operators in the UK today.
The first call made over a portable phone was made from St Katherine's dock to Vodafone's head office in Newbury on January 10th, 1985.
For the first nine days of 1985, Cellnet (now O2) launched its service and it quickly became popular among young people who wanted a mobile phone that was easy to use and affordable.
The first mobile phone call in the UK was made by Ernie Wise on January 1st, 1985.
Ernie was one of the first people in the UK to own a handset and he had been using it for several months before making the call.
The first mobile phone service in the UK was launched on January 10th, 1985 by Vodafone, which is still one of the largest operators in the UK today.
The first call made over a portable phone was made from St Katherine's dock to Vodafone's head office in Newbury on January 10th, 1985.
For the first nine days of 1985, Cellnet (now O2) launched its service and it quickly became popular among young people who wanted a mobile phone that was easy to use and affordable.
The first mobile phone call in the UK was made by Ernie Wise on January 1st, 1985.
Ernie was one of the first people in the UK to own a handset and he had been using it for several months before making the call.
The first mobile phone service in the UK was launched on January 10th, 1985 by Vodafone, which is still one of the largest operators in the UK today.
The first call made over a portable phone was made from St Catherine's dock to Vodafone's head office in Newbury on January 10th, 1985.
For the first nine days of 1985, Cellnet (now O2) launched its service and it quickly became popular among young people who wanted a mobile phone that was easy to use and affordable.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Mobile phones in the UK have been around for over two decades, celebrating their 20th anniversary.
The first call was made on January 1, 1985, between Ernie Wise (a comedian) and Vodafone.
Since then, mobile phones have become a key part of modern life, with nearly 90% of Britons owning one.
Many use their phone exclusively without landlines.
The UK set up mobile networks in 1985, which were later succeeded by O2 and Vodafone until 1983.
Vodafone started using analog radio for calls, which was easy to eavesdrop on with a £2k cost and limited battery life (just over 20 minutes).
It took nine years to reach one million customers and only 18 months for two million.
Vodafone's bid document in 1983 predicted a market of two million people but underestimated it as operators were few.
Vodafone dominated mobile networks until 1993 when One2One (now T-Mobile) launched, with Orange doing so in 1994.
After 1993, all operators switched to GSM technology, which is the most widely used phone service on the planet due to its ease of use and privacy.
Vodafone introduced features like text messaging and roaming, making mobile phones popular.
O2 (now Orange) and others have followed suit, adapting digital networks.
GSM has replaced analog calls, with O2 being the first to adopt it in the UK.
tinyllama:1.1b: Forty years ago, Britain's first mobile phone call was made across VoDAfonE's network in New York.
In the early days of its launch, only a handful of people had access to this technology.
Today, more than 90% of Britons own a mobile phone and almost all use them as their main communication tool.
Mobile phones became so popular that they revolutionized the way we communicate with each other.
Their unique features such as call waiting, caller ID, messaging, text messaging, and roaming have helped to make them so desirable and popular.
The growth of VoDAfonE, which was the only mobile phone operator in Britain when One2One launched in 1994, further emphasizes the significance of mobile phones in modern life.

Today, they are an integral part of our everyday routine, and their use is not limited to traditional communication methods like landlines or fixed-line services, but also includes digital technologies such as text messaging and mobile payments.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In the UK's early days, mobile phones were a luxury item for only a few wealthy individuals.
When Vodafone launched its services in 1985, it was only available to those with a significant income or access to expensive phones.
Cellnet and O2 both emerged during this period and became major players in the mobile phone market.
While Vodafone had a staggering number of customers at its peak, by the time it reached 1 billion users, it was not alone in its dominance.
Currently, there are over 14 million mobile users in the UK alone, with Vodafone itself accounting for over half of them.
The rise and fall of these telecommunications companies is a reflection of the changing landscape of technology and consumer preferences.
phi:2.7b: Mobile phones in the UK have been around for 20 years and were first introduced on 1 January 1985 with the first commercial mobile service being launched in 198
orca-mini:3b: In 1985, the first mobile phone call was made in the UK across the Vodafone network.
Ernie Wise made the historic call from St Katherine's dock to Vodafone's head office in Newbury on January 10th.
The UK was the first country in the world to launch mobile networks in the mid-1980s, and the first commercial mobile service was launched in the UK by Cellnet (now O2) on January 10th, 1985.
Despite using analogue radio signals for communication, mobile phones became a status symbol among young wealthy business folk, and were soon widely adopted.
Today, Vodafone has 14 million customers in the UK alone, and all operators use digital mobile networks.
The analogue spectrum for old phones has been retired, paving the way for new technologies such as GSM which is now the most widely used phone technology on the planet.
hermes3:3b: UK mobile phones turn 20; almost 90% Britons now own a handset, making them essential part of modern life since 1985's launch.
Initial models were large & expensive, analog signal, later replaced by digital GSM technology.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: In the UK, mobile phones are celebrating their 20th anniversary with almost 90% of Britons owning a handset.
The first commercial mobile service was launched in the UK in 1985, and Vodafone was the only firm offering a mobile network for the first nine days.
Now, Vodafone has 14 million customers, while Cellnet (now O2) and Orange were launched later, operating digital mobile networks.
The advent of digital technology played a significant role in the popularity of mobiles, introducing features like text messaging and roaming.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Mobile phones in the UK mark their 20th anniversary, with the first call made on 1 January 1985 by comedian Ernie Wise over Vodafone's network.
Since then, mobile phones have become essential, with nearly 90% of Britons owning one.
The first portable phone call was made in 1973 in New York, but commercial services took a decade to launch.
Vodafone initially dominated the UK market until Cellnet (now O2) launched on 10 January 1985.
Early mobile phones were large, expensive, and had short battery life but became status symbols.
Vodafone took nine years to reach one million customers but only 18 months for the second million.
By 1993, One2One (now T-Mobile) and Orange (1994) entered the market, introducing digital networks that replaced analogue systems.
The Global System for Mobiles (GSM) became the dominant technology, enabling features like text messaging and roaming, contributing to mobile phones' widespread popularity.
stablelm2:1.6b: Mobile phones are celebrating their 5th anniversary in the UK, with almost 90% of Britons owning a handset.
The first mobile call was made on January 1st 2005 by Ernie Wise on Vodafone network.
It took several years for commercial mobile services to be launched and during that time, Vodafone had the only mobile network in the UK.
Orange launched its UK service after Cellnet (now O2) did so earlier.
Today, all operators use digital mobile networks powered by Global System for Mobiles (GSM), now the most widely used phone technology globally, with over 1.2 billion people using it to make calls.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Mobile phones in the UK celebrate their 20th anniversary this weekend.

The first call on a portable phone was made in New York in 1973; the first commercial service in the UK, Vodafone, launched in 1985, with the first call between St Katherine's dock and Vodafone's head office in Newbury.
Initially, these phones were large, expensive ($2,000), and had short battery lives (20 minutes).
Despite this, they were popular among young, wealthy businesspeople due to their status symbol appeal.
By 1985, when Vodafone reached its first million customers, it took Cellnet (now O2) only 18 months to achieve the same milestone in the UK.

In 1993 and 1994, One2One (T-Mobile) and Orange entered the market, respectively, introducing digital technology that enhanced features like text messaging and global roaming, contributing to mobiles' widespread popularity.
Today, Vodafone has over 14 million customers in the UK, all using the Global System for Mobiles (GSM), the most widely adopted phone technology globally, supporting more than 1.2 billion users.

This technology transition from analogue to digital revolutionized mobile phones and fostered their integration into modern life, with nearly 90% of Britons now owning handsets, many using them as their primary phones instead of landlines.
